course_title: Advanced Therapy Skills: Working with Families and Groups

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and contrast the different approaches offered in family and group work , understand their application and critically evaluate clinical psychotherapy or art therapy family and group work literature.
identify the development of the frameworks, theoretical principles and application of therapy involving families and groups, recognising how it impacts on treatment planning and outcomes.
Develop and demonstrate your understanding of either group or family therapy approaches by applying this during your final assessment.
identify people and populations likely to benefit from group and or family interventions and be able to demonstrate a specific approach for a specific population.

assessments.task_description:
Type: Journal

Weight: 30%

Task Description:

Over the course of the semester students are expected to complete 8 journal entries, 300 words +/- 10%. Art Therapy journal entries include a visual reflection (1-2 images per entry).

Each journal entry is to be completed by the Sunday after the selected tutorial, as response and analysis of the tutorial readings and discussion, and should include the following:

  1. Key aspects of the literature that stood out to you
  2. How the frameworks/interventions discussed resonate with you and your practice
  3. The final inclusion differs per area of speciality:
  • Art Therapy: what the art work created conveys (and how), and how does it support your learning
  • Psychotherapy: Any ethical or cultural consideration the content raised for you 


The student must post their journal reflection on blackboard.


Criteria & Marking (Art Therapy):

1. Journal entries are original and show evidence that the reading and class discussion has been analysed and responded to in a thoughtful and reflective manner.

2. The prompting journal questions have been considered and responded to appropriately.

3. Art work is clearly presented and the quality of media, process of art making, and visual reflection is described.

4. There are 10 journal entries that are on time, are within the word limit, are free of spelling and grammatical errors, and which demonstrate appropriate care with the task.


Criteria & Marking (Psychotherapy):

1. Journal entries are original and show evidence that the reading and discussion has been analysed and responded to in a thoughtful and reflective manner i.e. consideration of any cultural or ethical issues, and/ or integrating theory with clinical examples from practice where possible or appropriate.

2. The prompting journal questions have been considered and responded to appropriately

3. There are 10 journal entries that are on time, within the word limit, free of spelling and grammatical errors, and which demonstrate appropriate care with the task.

assessments.task_description:
Type: Essay

Learning Objectives Assessed: 1, 2, 3, 4

Word Count: 2000 +/- 10% 

Task Description:

Discuss a therapeutic intervention for a family - outlining theoretical frameworks and why you have used the application for this particular client group. Art Therapy students must include family art therapy interventions.

Students are required to identify and discuss a population which could benefit from family therapy intervention. Students are required to describe the population, articulate their needs, explain how family [art] therapy could be beneficial, and identify family therapy strategies which may benefit the population. Assertions about the population and their needs must be backed up by reference to a range of sources including: recent literature, personal investigation and clinical or placement experience if relevant.

Criteria & Marking:

1. Student has identified an appropriate population who could benefit from a family [art] therapy intervention. The population is described and their needs and challenges are articulated. 

2. The reason family [art] therapy could be beneficial, including the choice of family strategies and intervention is articulated, and supported by literature.

3. Essay is in an appropriate academic form and structure, is well written and free from grammatical and spelling errors. Referencing and citation uses standard format and the essay is 2000 words (+/- 10%).

assessments.task_description:
Mode: Oral 

Category: Presentation

Learning Outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Task Description:

Prepare and deliver a 20-minute oral presentation proposing a group therapy intervention relevant to your current professional context or area of interest. 

1.  Target Population: Identify and justify a specific population that would benefit from a group [art] therapy approach. 

2.  Group Intervention/ Activities: Develop an appropriate group [art] intervention tailored to the needs of the chosen population. Your proposal must be grounded in current literature, demonstrating an understanding of the therapeutic needs, strengths, and potential challenges associated with the group. 

3.  Evidence Base: Provide a clear rationale for your proposed group [art] therapy model. Draw on contemporary research and relevant theoretical frameworks to justify the suitability and effectiveness of your intervention for the identified population. 

4.  Group Structure and Process: Explain the format and structure of your proposed group (e.g., open vs. closed, session frequency, facilitation style, therapeutic approach). Support your decisions with literature that outlines best practices in group facilitation and therapeutic outcomes. 

5.  Discussion Component: Following your presentation, you will participate in a 10-minute discussion facilitated by the Course Coordinator and fellow students. This is an opportunity to respond to questions, clarify your approach, and reflect on feedback.
